info.game_comments:
Trevor Norris game 3.

(Sofia: I'm Sofia of the Clue Crew at the Page Museum and the La Brea Tar Pits.  We've got some new fossils for you today on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: This catcher known for his malaprops said of a restaurant, "Nobody goes there anymore.  It's too crowded"

(2, 1).clue: Popular Greek beverages include beer & retsina, a type of this potent potable flavored by pine resin

(3, 1).clue: For over 40 years, Virginia City, an old mining town in this state, has hosted yearly camel races

(4, 1).clue: On Feb. 2, 1986 this important religious leader met with the Dalai Lama in India

(5, 1).clue: ...corned beef, Swiss cheese & sauerkraut sandwich on rye that is fried & named this

(6, 1).clue: In 1826, on his deathbed, he said, "This is the 4th?"

(1, 2).clue: Catfish Hunter said when you unwrap a candy bar named for this ex-Yank seen here, "It tells you how good it is"

(2, 2).clue: About 1% of the population of Greece is ethnically from this neighboring European country

(3, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew is at the Orange County Fair.)  Mostly made of fat, this part of the camel can weigh over 80 pounds

(4, 2).clue: Of 5, 15 or 25, the age at which the current Dalai Lama got the job

(5, 2).clue: ...Denver omelet, which is usually made with ham, onion & the bell type of these

(6, 2).clue: Richmond man who asked "Bugsy" co-star Annette "If she wanted to have dinner and have a baby and she said 'Yes'"

(1, 3).clue: Where have you gone, this Yankee slugger?  At age 18, it was to the midst of a 61-game Pacific Coast League hit streak

(2, 3).clue: A limestone hill in the southwest of Athens, it houses the temple of Athena Nike

(3, 3).clue: (Alex: Jimmy's still there.)  Camel hairs are sometimes used to make these for artists

(4, 3).clue: This country denounced the awarding of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize to the Dalai Lama as politically motivated

(5, 3).clue: ...bowl of this Creole specialty, whose name comes from an African word for okra

(6, 3).clue: Born in Roanoke in 1942, his most famous song includes "Danke Schoen, thank you for walks down Lovers' Lane"

(1, 4).clue: In 1956 this Oklahoman won the Triple Crown, hitting .353, with 52 HRs & 130 RBIs

(2, 4).clue: Greece's national emblem features a white cross surrounded by a wreath of this

(3, 4).clue: From the Greek for "running", it's another name for the Arabian camel

(4, 4).clue: These dogs developed in Tibet historically have been given as gifts to dignitaries by the Dalai Lama

(5, 4).clue: ...pita dipped in this thick Middle Eastern sauce made from chickpeas

(6, 4).clue: Born in Wise, he called the 1970 Oscars "a 2-hour meat parade, a public display with contrived suspense"

(1, 5).clue: This "Iron Horse" pulled himself from the Yankee lineup on May 2, 1939 after 2,130 consecutive games

(2, 5).clue: The excavated ancient palace of Knossos can be seen when visiting this large Greek island

(3, 5).clue: 2 of the 4 members of the camel family that live in South America

(4, 5).clue: The fifth Dalai Lama was installed as Tibet's leader in 1642 by Gushri Khan, the leader of these people

(5, 5).clue: ...creamy potato & leek soup served cold that's called this

(6, 5).clue: "You can't hold a man down without staying down with him" is attributed to this "Up from Slavery" author born in Virginia

(1, 1).clue: In the Battle of Trenton, these German mercenaries were under the command of Col. Johann Rall

(2, 1).clue: (Hi, I'm Danny Nucci.)  I played Fabrizio De Rossi, Leonardo DiCaprio's best friend, in this 1997 blockbuster

(3, 1).clue: In 1899 this composer wrote the "Maple Leaf Rag", which increased the popularity of ragtime music

(5, 1).clue: "Get down to" these & you're working on what's important

(6, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew is at the Page Museum.)  Correct scientific name of this ancient beast; 60 million of his descendants once roamed North America

(1, 2).clue: As the war dawned, America's main arms storehouse was located in this town about 20 miles from Boston

(2, 2).clue: This actor pursues class brain Ione Skye in 1989's "Say Anything..."

(3, 2).clue: This major German composed the overture in C major heard here

(5, 2).clue: This H.G. Wells title device came back "A little travel worn...a brass rail bent"

(6, 2).clue: When a Mr. has 2 Mrs., he's committing this

(1, 3).clue: The Battle of Monmouth on June 28, 1778 in this state was the last major battle in the north

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew is at the beach, dressed in a black wig; with Jimmy right behind her.)  The tagline from this 1965 Frankie & Annette movie was "It's a game -- separate the girls & the boys into groups of two"

(5, 3).clue: The instruments in a brass band range in pitch from the cornet to the bombardon, a bass one of these

(6, 3).clue: Term for something that occurs every 2 years

(1, 4).clue: In 1778 this American captain & his crew looted the Earl of Selkirk's caste in Solway Firth, Scotland

(2, 4).clue: Daniel Day-Lewis says, "You stay alive, no matter what occurs!" in this 1992 film of a James Fenimore Cooper classic

(3, 4).clue: The explosive conclusion of this Tchaikovsky composition is heard here

(5, 4).clue: Architectural bronze is a brass alloy of mainly this metal with a little lead, tin & zinc thrown in

(6, 4).clue: Alternating between manic & depressive states is part of this affective disorder

(1, 5).clue: In May 1775 Benedict Arnold & Ethan Allen captured Forts Crown Point & Ticonderoga on this lake

(2, 5).clue: (Hi, I'm Rob Schneider.)  This "Survivor" co-starred in my 2001 comedy "The Animal"

(3, 5).clue: At his peak he composed 2 or 3 operas a year like "Lucia di Lammermoor"

(5, 5).clue: The art of this involves taking a crayon or wax stick to paper atop a design in metal to transfer the design

(6, 5).clue: Also called a cocked hat, this hat with the front brim turned up was popular around 1800

(0, 0).clue: It's the only island whose territory makes up parts of 3 different independent nations
